docs.title: What is TypeScript
docs.description: TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript that adds static types to the language. It allows developers to write more predictable and maintainable code by catching errors at compile-time rather than runtime. TypeScript code is transpiled to JavaScript, making it compatible with all JavaScript environments.

docs.title: Strong Typing
docs.description: TypeScript enforces strong typing, meaning that variables, parameters, and return values must have specific data types. This helps prevent unexpected behaviors and errors in the code. Strong typing also improves code readability and provides better editor support, such as autocompletion and type checking.

docs.title: Static vs. Dynamic Typing
docs.description: In TypeScript, types are checked at compile-time, which is known as static typing. This means that type errors are caught before the code is executed. In contrast, dynamic typing in languages like JavaScript checks types at runtime, potentially leading to errors during program execution.

docs.title: Type Annotations
docs.description: Type annotations in TypeScript are used to explicitly specify the data type of a variable, parameter, or return value. For example, 'let age: number = 30;' declares a variable 'age' of type 'number'. Type annotations enhance code clarity and enable the TypeScript compiler to catch type-related errors.

docs.title: Type Inference
docs.description: TypeScript has a powerful type inference system that automatically deduces the data type of a variable if it is not explicitly specified. This means developers can write concise code without necessarily specifying types everywhere. For example, 'let name = "John";' will infer the type of 'name' as 'string'.

docs.title: TypeScript vs. JavaScript
docs.description: While JavaScript is a dynamically typed language, TypeScript offers static typing, allowing developers to catch type-related errors during development. TypeScript code is transpiled to JavaScript, making it compatible with all JavaScript environments. TypeScript also supports the latest ECMAScript features, providing developers with modern language features.

docs.title: Benefits of Using TypeScript
docs.description: Using TypeScript offers several benefits, including improved code quality due to static typing, enhanced code readability, better editor support with features like autocompletion and refactoring, and early error detection. TypeScript also facilitates easier maintenance of large codebases and provides excellent tooling and community support.

docs.title: Setting Up TypeScript
docs.description: To start using TypeScript, developers need to install it globally or locally in their project. They can create a 'tsconfig.json' file to configure TypeScript options, such as target ECMAScript version, module system, and output directory. TypeScript can be compiled using the 'tsc' command, generating JavaScript files from the TypeScript source code.

docs.title: Boolean
docs.description: Represents a true or false value.
docs.code:
let isDone: boolean = true;
let isEnabled: boolean = false;

docs.title: Number
docs.description: Represents numeric values.

docs.title: String
docs.description: Represents textual data.
docs.code:
let firstName: string = 'John';
let greeting: string = `Hello, ${firstName}!`;

docs.title: Array
docs.description: Represents a list of values.
docs.code:
let numbers: number[] = [1, 2, 3];
let names: string[] = ['Alice', 'Bob', 'Charlie'];

docs.title: Tuple
docs.description: Represents an array with fixed-length and specific element types.
docs.code: let tuple: [string, number] = ['John', 30];

docs.title: Enum
docs.description: A way to give more friendly names to sets of numeric values.

docs.title: Any
docs.description: Represents any data type, allowing for dynamic behavior.

docs.title: Void
docs.description: Represents absence of any type. Typically used as the return type of functions that do not return a value.

docs.title: Null and Undefined
docs.description: Have their own types 'null' and 'undefined', respectively.
docs.code:
let nullValue: null = null;
let undefinedValue: undefined = undefined;

docs.title: Never
docs.description: Represents the type of values that never occur.

docs.title: Type Annotations
docs.description: Explicitly specify the data type of a variable, parameter, or return value.

docs.title: Type Inference
docs.description: Automatically deduce the data type based on the value assigned.

docs.title: Type Aliases
docs.description: Create a new name for a type, making the code more readable.
docs.code:
type Point = { x: number; y: number };
let p: Point = { x: 10, y: 20 };

docs.title: Intersection Types
docs.description: Combine multiple types into one, containing all properties of the merged types.

docs.title: Union Types
docs.description: Combine multiple types into one, allowing flexibility in variable or parameter types.

docs.title: Intersection Types
docs.description: Combine multiple types into one, containing all properties of the merged types.

docs.title: Type Guards
docs.description: Narrow down the type of a variable within a specific block of code.

docs.title: Typeof Type Guards
docs.description: Narrow down the type of a variable using the 'typeof' operator.

docs.title: Instanceof Type Guards
docs.description: Check if an object is an instance of a specific class or constructor function.

docs.title: Mapped Types
docs.description: Create new types by transforming each property of an existing type.

docs.title: Generics
docs.description: Create reusable components that work with a variety of types.

docs.title: Interfaces
docs.description: Define the structure of an object, allowing you to specify the types of its properties and methods.

docs.title: Class Declaration
docs.description: Define a blueprint for creating objects with a constructor and methods.

docs.title: Inheritance
docs.description: Create a new class based on an existing class, inheriting its properties and methods.

docs.title: Implements
docs.description: Implement an interface in a class, ensuring that the class adheres to the interface's structure.

docs.title: Generic Functions
docs.description: Write functions that work with multiple data types without sacrificing type safety.

docs.title: Generic Classes
docs.description: Create classes with properties and methods that work with a variety of data types.

docs.title: Generic Constraints
docs.description: Restrict the types that can be used with generics based on their properties or methods.

docs.title: Generic Utility Types
docs.description: Use predefined generic utility types to manipulate and transform types.

docs.title: Function Declaration
docs.description: Create a named function with specified parameters and return type.

docs.title: Function Expressions
docs.description: Assign a function to a variable, allowing functions to be treated as values.

docs.title: Arrow Functions
docs.description: Create concise anonymous functions using the arrow syntax.

docs.title: Optional and Default Parameters

docs.title: Function Overloads

docs.title: Promises
